So yesterday, after a time void of KSP (sad, I know ) I downloaded .21, made a new save and got back to experimenting! First, I sent a satellite into orbit around Kerbin, the Mun and Minmus. That was pretty standard, so It's not worth going into detail on.

But today, I wanted to land a rover on the Mun. I had tried before, but was not successful, especially since I'm rubbish at building the actual rovers. So, I ended up with a plate on top of the biggest battery with wheels and solar panels. On my first attempt, I crashed, so I redesigned some things and successfully landed! But then I realized there was something on top of my rover that I couldn't get rid of.

There was a stack decoupler (that let my sky crane fly away using seperatrons) and an ASAS (can't remember what it's called now) making it hard to drive around. So then I drove around for a bit and got flipped. Then I realized that those parts now provide torque! So basically, unless I break something I can use the rover and flip it as much as I want!

So anyway, next I'm going to try and accomplish what I tried without success last time: Building a Mun base! Muhahahaha
Always nice to see the birth of another mad scientist

I was wondering why my Whackjob sense was tingling.

It's fun to have spaceship-grade reaction wheel systems on little rovers.

Somewhere along the line while making a Curiosity reenactment, I decided to center it on a SAS module. This worked well in flight, and now, I can pull interesting stunts with the rover.

I also made something that flips itself over with SAS to climb the VAB.

Reaction wheels are cool.
Just so you know, going into docking mode will basically turn off the torque in translation mode. It is good for driving around.

Mad scientist indeed!
